The Impact of Severe Storms across the US

Mar 12, 2022

By WILLIAM DAY

As global climate change brings more severe weather more frequently, areas around the United States will experience varying levels of disruption. Between 2010 and 2020, the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Association catalogued 110,394 severe weather events across the country, accounting for over $245 billion in property damage.

Flooding

20,359 events

$121 billion damage

Flooding occurs nationwide, but is concentrated along coasts and major waterways

Tornadoes and Wind

46,782 events

$37 billion damage

Tornadoes and wind affect much of the US, but especially impact the Midwest and South

Hurricanes

372 events

$43 billion damage

Hurricanes are geographically isolated, but result in catastrophic property damage

Damage (millions of dollars)

0.1

15.2

Several counties in Texas, Louisiana, and Florida suffered over $15.2 billion in hurricane-caused property damage during the last decade

Wildfires

3,149 events

$23 billion damage

Wildfires appear sporadically, but are often found in Texas, along the Rockies, and on the west coast

Damage (millions of dollars)

0

0.03

0.5

2.18

Between 2010 and 2020, Washington, California, and Texas all experienced their largest wildfires in state history.

Source: NOAA Storm Events Database

Notes: Flood, tornado, and wind damage reported and displayed at a county level. Hurricane and wildfire damage is reported and displayed according to NWS forecast zones. NWS zones typically align with counties, especially in the eastern two thirds of the country. The west coast shows greater disparities between county and NWS forecast borders.
